DOC.HEAD: Frank Lloyd Wright Colleagues Blast New Jail Design
DOC.TEXT: Associates of Frank Lloyd Wright have asked Marin County officials to redesign a proposed $23 million jail rather than ``denigrate'' the memory of the renowned architect. The two-story jail, with up to 219 cells, would be built in front of one of Wright's most famous works _ the Marin County Civic Center, whose pale pink arches sweep across three small knolls along busy U.S. Highway 101. The center is the only government building designed by Wright that actually was built. William Wesley Peters, senior architect and chairman of the board of trustees of the Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation, and San Francisco architect Aaron Green, who worked closely with Wright, wrote to the county Board of Supervisors last week, saying they were appalled by the jail design. They asked that it be redone to harmonize with the Wright's building. The rectangular jail would stand 24 feet high and would obscure much of the view of the civic center. The project is ``callously different from the soft and graceful lines of Frank Lloyd Wright's Hall of Justice and Administration Building'' and would be ``the antithesis of what Frank Lloyd Wright had so creatively conceived,'' Green wrote. Peters told supervisors the project ``would seriously denigrate Frank Lloyd Wright's legacy to Marin County, to California and to the world.'' But county supervisors, who are under court order to relieve jail crowding, say it is unlikely the design will be significantly changed. ``We just don't have time,'' said Supervisor Al Aramburu. ``It's the best we could do, given the site.'' Construction must begin by next fall so the county can qualify for state money for the project. ``If the board is to stop this, its members should be thrown in jail. It would be criminal to lose the state bond money,'' said Robert Stockwell, president of the board.
